text: If there's a lot of feedback to give, or sometimes even if not, our editor will record a short loom vid for writers rather than just comments on a doc, it's way more personable and you can convey tone rather than a harmless suggestion being taken the wrong way or out of context :slightly_smiling_face:

text: Adding to the great thoughts above -- in addition to basic attention to culture, we have a monthly personnel mtg where we (editors) talk about each writer one by one. That way we can identify both exemplary work and systemic issues that should be addressed, and identify opportunities for further training. We also use this mtg to talk about which writers might be ready to move to more advanced projects.

text:
<@U02AJEYF538> I like the loom idea. Try to soften the blow by putting a human face behind it. I think there's definitely a need for a "compliment sandwich" approach like <@U02JJ9PJ4SG> is talking about. We're a fully remote/distributed organization but <@U01NJ39M36K> and <@UUJBPA9K5>'s idea around finding ways to help them build relationships is something to noodle on.

For everyone else, here's what I'm thinking of doing — putting together a "Writer/Editor Communication Commandments" to help both parties understand how they should expect to share and receive feedback, and guidelines for making hard feedback feel less personal (kind of like what your'e saying <@UUJBPA9K5> with some tone softening). I would ask both parties to review at the beginning of our working relationship and refer them back to it for any changes or if I'm getting feedback that they're not following it. We have something like this I put together for my AMs and PMs to communicate with each other, the internal team, and clients/vendors and I think it's helped to get everyone on the same page as far as expectations.
